review.title: Sentiment of Emojis
review.abstract: There is a new generation of emoticons, called emojis, increasingly used in mobile communications and social media. In the last two years, over ten billion of emojis were used on Twitter. Emojis are Unicode graphic symbols, used as a shorthand to express concepts and ideas. In contrast to a small number of well-known emoticons which carry clear emotional contents, there are hundreds of emojis. But what is their emotional contents? We provide the first emoji sentiment lexicon, called Emoji Sentiment Ranking, and draw a sentiment map of the 751 most frequently used emojis. The sentiment of emojis is computed from the sentiment of tweets in which they occur. We have engaged 83 human annotators to label over 1.6 million tweets in 13 European languages by the sentiment polarity (negative, neutral, or positive). About 4\% of the annotated tweets contain emojis. The sentiment analysis of emojis yields several interesting conclusions. It turns out that most of the emojis are positive, especially the most popular ones. The sentiment distribution of the tweets with and without emojis is significantly different. The inter-annotator agreement on the tweets with emojis is higher. Emojis tend to occur at the end of the tweets, and their sentiment polarity increases with the distance. We observe no significant differences in emoji rankings between the 13 languages, and propose our Emoji Sentiment Ranking as a European language-independent resource for automated sentiment analysis. Finally, the paper provides a formalization of sentiment and novel visualization in the form of a sentiment bar.

In the last two years, over ten billion emojis have been used on Twitter. Emojis are graphical Unicode symbols that are used as an abbreviation to express concepts and ideas. Unlike a small number of well-known emoticons that carry clear emotional content, there are hundreds of emojis. But what is their emotional content? We provide the first emoji sentiment lexicon, called Emoji Sentiment Ranking, and draw a sentiment map of the 751 most commonly used emojis. The feeling of emojis is calculated from the feeling of tweets in which they occur. We have engaged 83 human annotators to mark over 1.6 million tweets in 13 European languages according to the sentiment polarity (negative, neutral or neutral).

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text: An emoticon, as it is known from English, is a shorthand for devices such as smartphones and tablets. It allows the author to express his feelings, feelings and emotions and expands a written message with non-verbal elements. It helps to attract the attention of the reader and improves the understanding of the message. However, an emoji is a step forward, developed with modern communication technologies that allow expressive messages in which a graphic symbol, an ideogram that represents not only facial expressions, but also concepts and ideas, such as the weather, vehicles and buildings, animals and plants, or emotions, feelings and activists that have become extremely popular on smartphones, in chats and email applications. For example, Instagram, a mobile photo sharing and a social networking platform reported in March 2015, is that almost half of texts on Instagram contain emojis [1].

sections.text: A large pool of tweets, in 13 European languages, is therefore often referred to as emoji by 83 native speakers. Emojis can take one of three ordered values: negative, neutral, positive. An emoji label, c, is formally a discrete, 3-valid variable c emoji (emoji number) {− 1, 0, + 1}. An emoji is associated with a feeling from all tweets in which it occurs. First, we form a discrete probability distribution (p −, p0, p +) for each emoji. The emoji's sentiment value is then calculated as the mean of the distribution. The components of the distribution: p −, p0, and p + denote the negativity, neutrality and positivity of the emoji. sections.heading: Emoji sentiment map
sections.text: Before analyzing the characteristics of tweets with emojis, we will first discuss two visualizations of Emoji Sentiment Ranking. Figure 2 shows the general map of 751 emojis. The position of an emoji is determined by its tweets, while the negative tweets are on the left side of the tweet (red). The sentiment score s is in the range (-1, + 1) and is calculated as p + − p. The more positive emojis are on the right side of the map (green), while the negative tweets are on the left side (red). Neutral emojis (yellow) span an entire band around s = 0. Emojis are predominantly positive, the mean sentiment score is + 0.3 (see Fig 4). The bubble is proportional to the number of tweets occurring. A more detailed view of some actual emotions on the map is in Fig 3. The most common negative emojis (Panel A) are sad faces.

sections.heading: Sentiment distribution
sections.text: In this subsection, we analyze the mood distribution of emojis in terms of the frequency of their use. The question we raise is: Are the more commonly used emojis emotionally stressed? First, in Figure 4, we show the mood distribution of the 751 emojis, regardless of their frequency. It is obvious that the mood value of the emojis is roughly normally distributed, with mean = + 0.3, predominantly positive. In Figure 5, we evaluate the emojis by the number of occurrences in tweets. The mood value of each emoji is indicated by the color. The zoomed-in section of the first 33 emojis in Figure 6. We did not carefully analyze the frequency distribution of the emojis. A quick analysis suggests that the data follow a power law with an exponential cutoff to rank about 200. Using the maximum probability estimator [26], the exponent of the power law is − 1,3, a relatively extreme exponent.

sections.heading: Sentiment and emoji position
sections.text: Where are emojis typically placed in tweets? Emoticons such as: -) are used sparingly and typically at the very end of a sentence. Emojis, on the other hand, appear in groups and not just at the end of tweets. Figure 7 shows the average position of the 751 emojis in tweets. On average, an emoji is placed at 2 / 3 of the length of a tweet. Figure 7 also shows the mood of an emoji in relation to its position. In Figure 8, we break down the feeling into its three components and show regression trend lines. The linear regression functions in Figure 8 take the following forms: Negativity: p − (d) = 0.20d + 0.03 (R 2 = 0.06), Neutrality: p0 (d) = − 0.41d + 0.66 (R2 = 0.14), Positivity: p + (d) = 0.21 d + 0.04), where d is the distance from the beginning of the tweet.

sections.heading: Emojis in different languages
sections.text: In the last subsection, we analyze the use of emojis in the 13 languages processed in this study. Can Emoji Sentiment Ranking be considered a universal resource, at least for the European languages? Does the sentiment ranking differ significantly between the different languages? The results in Table 5 indicate that the answer to the second question is negative. For each language, we compute a list of emojis used in the language's collected tweets, truncate emojis with less than 5 occurrences (the same threshold as for the entire Emoji Sentiment Ranking) and calculate their sentiment score. We calculate the correlation coefficients between the Emoji Sentiment Ranking and the individual languages. As shown in Table 5, the number of emojis actually used in different languages (above the threshold) decreases considerably. However, their sentiment scores and ranking remain stable. Both the correlation between the Emoji Sentiment Ranking and the ranking of the album correlation between all languages are relatively high and exceptionally high.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text: In this paper, we describe the construction of an emoji sentiment lexicon, emoji sentiment ranking, the first such resource to be openly available. We have thoroughly formalized and analyzed the sentiment characteristics of emojis, and highlighted some interesting conclusions. Data that enabled this analysis, 1.6 million commented tweets in 13 different languages, are a valuable resource with many other useful applications. In particular, we construct sentiment classification models for different languages and apply them to different tasks. Slovenian and Bulgarian language sentiment models have already been applied to monitor sentiment on Twitter in real time during political elections [27]. The English sentiment model has been used to compare the sentiment leanings of different retweeted network communities toward various environmental issues [28]. A domain-specific English sentiment model (from another set of financial tweets) has been applied to analyze the impact of Twitter sentiment on stock prices [29].

sections.heading: Data collection
sections.text: The main source of data used in this study is a collection of tweets in 13 European languages collected between April 2013 and February 2015. Most tweets (except English) were collected as part of a collaborative project with the Gama System (http: / / www.gama-system.si) using its EmotionAnalytics platform (http: / / www.perceptionanalytics.net). Tweets from selected languages were collected via the Twitter Search API by specifying the geolocations of the largest cities. For English tweets, we used the Twitter Streaming API (a random sample of 1% of all public tweets) and filtered out the English postings. We hired 83 native speakers (except English) to manually comment on the mood of over 1.6 million tweets collected. The annotation process was supported by the Stieglitz platform (provided by Sowa Labs, http: / / www.sowalabs.com), which was specifically designed for the sensation of short texts.

sections.heading: Emoji Unicode symbols
sections.text: The precise definition of what constitutes an emoji symbol is still emerging. In particular, there is a certain discrepancy between our set of emojis and the emojis followed by Emojitracker. Also during the writing of this paper, in August 2015, the Unicode Consortium released a new set of emojis, the Unicode Emoji Charts (http: / / www.unicode.org / emoji /).The set of emojis in our Emoji Sentiment Ranking follows the standard Unicode version 8 [15] and consists of all the single-character symbols in the Unicode Symbol, Miscellaneous category (abbreviated [So]) that appear in our tweets. Emojitracker also tracks some double-character symbols (10 country symbols and 11 combination symbols that enclose key symbols), but not all the [So] symbols that appear in our data.

sections.heading: Sentiment bar
sections.text: The Sentiment Bar is a useful new visualization of the mood attributed to an emoji (see examples: http: / / kt.ijs.si / data / Emoji _ sentiment _ ranking /). In a single image, it captures all the sentiment properties calculated from the sentiment distribution of emoji occurrences: p −, p0, p +, s ², and s ± 1.96sem (the 95% confidence interval). An example of how the sentiment properties are mapped into the graphical characteristics can be found in Figure 9.

sections.heading: Welch’s t-test
sections.text: Welch's t-test [23] is used to test the hypothesis that two populations have equal mean values. It is an adjustment of the students "t-test, but is more reliable if the two samples have unequal deviations and sample sizes. Welch's t-test is also robust for distorted distributions and large sample sizes [24]. Welch's t-test defines the t-statistic as follows: t = x x x x x x x x x x x 2 √ sd2 1 N1 + sd2 2 2 2 N2. Degrees of freedom are estimated as follows: ν (sd2 1N1 + sd2 2 N2) 2sd4 1N2 1 (N1 − 1) + sd4 2N2 2 2 2 2 (N2 − 1), with the p-value indicating the approximate degrees of freedom rounded down to the nearest integer. Once the t-value and degree of freedom are determined, a value for the p-t students can be found.

sections.heading: Pearson and Spearman correlation
sections.text: We have to correlate two properties of the Emoji Sentiment Ranking with other data: In the first case, we correlate emojis according to the occurrence on the Emojitracker list - the property of the list elements is the number of occurrences. In the second case, we correlate emojis according to the feeling on subsets of emojis from the 13 different languages - the property of the list elements is the sentiment score. For all two lists x and y, of length n, we first compute the Pearson correlation coefficient [21]: r (x, y) = ∑ n = 1 (xi − x) (yi − y і). The rank correlation coefficient [22] is calculated the same way, the property values of the x elements and y elements are simply replaced by their precedence, where x-y values are the list averages or rank correlations on the level 1%.

sections.heading: Agreement measures
sections.text: In general, the similarity between two methods of generating data can be estimated. In our case, we want to estimate the similarity between people when commenting on the same tweets for sentimentality. A comparison of the similarity between different sets of data gives an indication of how difficult chance is. There are different measures of similarity, and in order to obtain a robust estimate of differences, we apply three well-known metrics. (Note: Alpha reliability [25] is a generalization of several specialized parameters of similarity. It works for any number of annotators applicable to different variable types and metrics (e.g., nominal, ordered, interval,.) and can handle small sample sizes. Alpha is defined as follows: Alpha = 1 − Do, where discrepancy between annotators is observed, and De is discrepancy expected by chance.
